moves.3. Nf3 Nc6: Nc6 - although not a popular move is nevertheless a sound enough move
moves.7... Be7 8. e5: This pawn advance is perhaps premature
After several exchanges this position may be slightly better for Black: Black has only two pawn islands compared with White's three; White's King is looking a little exposed
moves.12... Bc5+ 13. Kg2 Nh5 14. e6: Losing the pushed pawn by a simple fork
moves.18. Ne4 Bb6 19. Ng5 Ke7: Defending the e-pawn whilst accepting the loss of the h-pawn
moves.20. Rde1 Rf6 21. Nxh7 Rxf3 22. Ng5 Rf6 2: White has gathered all his pieces on the e-pawn and Black is tied to its defense
moves.25. Nh7 Rf2: An active looking move but if the Knight returns to g5 then the Rook must retreat to defend the pawn.
moves.26. Re1e2: Instead White allows an exchange of Rooks
moves.26... Rxe2 27. Rxe2 Rd5: A seemingly quiet move that actually threatens to trap the Knight with Rh5 (which my opponent missed)
moves.28. Kg2 Rh5: The knight is trapped although after White plays the knight to e8 he is able to capture the e-pawn.  However, the position is such now that this is not enough for White
moves.29. Nf8 Kxf8 30. Rxe6 Kf7 31. Re2 Rh6 32: To keep the Rook, White must forfeit the c-pawn and it's difficult to see any counter-play for White. As it is, White decides to exchange Rooks which leaves Black with a decisive advantage
The wrong idea - the correct plan is to immedtiately march the King over to the queenside and capture White's pawn and promote his own.  Although this plan was played out eventually, the text shows that Black was too slow
Only now is the winning plan clearly implemented
